form_title.ms_form_title_llm_v1: Screeneded by NARA, 7/24/2024, NARA Form Number: 15-368

full_text: Screened by NARA, 7/24/2023 Your fee waiver request and associated application or petition is being returned to you. If you wish to re-apply for the above noted immigration benefit you must resubmit the application or petition with the required filing fee to the appropriate INS office. If you feel the denial of your fee waiver request is incorrect, you may submit a new fee waiver request with additional supporting information when you resubmit your associated application/petition. It would be helpful for any additional information that you submit to include a more complete description of your financial and living situation, with supporting documentation. For example you may wish to include: An itemized list of your individual and household income, assets, and expenses for the last year, on a MONTHLY basis; Supporting individual and household income documentation such as - Employment records, pay stubs, W-2 forms, letter(s) from employer(s), and income tax returns (proof of filing of a tax return). The same documents may also be submitted for your dependents in the United States; Supporting assets documentation such as - Documentation to show all assets owned, possessed, or controlled by you, or your dependents; Supporting expenses documentation such as - Utility bills (such as gas, electricity, telephone, water) and receipts for rent, food, medical expenses, child care, and other essential expenditures; Evidence that you have (within the last 180 days) qualified for or received a "federal means- tested public benefit." "Federal means-tested public benefits" include, but are not limited to Food Stamps, Medicaid, Supplemental Security Income, and Temporary Assistance of Needy Families; Evidence which verifies that you have a disability. You may provide verification of your disability by submitting documentation showing that the disability has been previously determined by the SSA, HHS, DOD, or other appropriate federal agency; Evidence of your living arrangements in the United States (living with relative, living in your own house, apartment, etc.), and evidence of whether your spouse, children, or other dependents are residing in your household in the United States; Evidence of your essential extraordinary expenditures, or those of your dependents residing in the United States; A detailed explanation of any other extenuating or unique circumstances you believe should be considered in determining your "inability to pay" the required filing fee.
